title: How to Make Banana Raspberry Pie

steps.headline: Mix the sugar, cornstarch, salt, and cinnamon in a large bowl.
steps.description: Then add the more delicate ingredient (the raspberries) after these items are well mixed. This will help to try to avoid breaking them apart or squishing them as you mix.

steps.headline: Store this newly mixed pie filling in the refrigerator.
Take the first pie crust.
steps.description: Mush it into a dough form, flatten it, and cut it into several ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) strips. If you have trouble turning the pie crust into dough, sprinkle it with water until it cooperates.

steps.headline: Take the second pie crust.
steps.description: Brush the inside of the pie crust, especially the center, with a thin layer of egg white. This will keep the crust from getting soggy later.

steps.headline: Cut a banana into slices.
steps.description: Make the slices ⁄4 to ⁄2 inch (0.6 to 1.3 cm) thick. Line the second pie crust with the slices.

steps.headline: Set your oven to preheat at 350ºF.
steps.description: From this point, you need to work quickly so that your oven does not get too hot before you put the pie in.

steps.headline: Pour the pie filling, which has been sitting in the refrigerator, into the pie crust (over the top of the bananas).
steps.description: Smooth it with the rounded side of a big spoon.

steps.headline: Create a lattice top on the pie, using the strips prepared in Step 3.
steps.description: With a fork, press the ends down onto the crust. Use a little bit of water to help stick if they do not stick of their own accord.

steps.headline: Brush the lattice top strips with egg white and sprinkle with sugar and cinnamon.
Wrap the crust in foil.
steps.description: Doing this helps to prevent the crust from burning on the edges before the center of the pie is thoroughly cooked.

steps.headline: Place the pie into the center of the oven.
Remove the pie and let it cool for at least an hour before you eat it.

text: Mix the sugar, cornstarch, salt, and cinnamon in a large bowl. Then add the more delicate ingredient (the raspberries) after these items are well mixed. This will help to try to avoid breaking them apart or squishing them as you mix. Store this newly mixed pie filling in the refrigerator.  Take the first pie crust. Mush it into a dough form, flatten it, and cut it into several ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) strips. If you have trouble turning the pie crust into dough, sprinkle it with water until it cooperates. Take the second pie crust. Brush the inside of the pie crust, especially the center, with a thin layer of egg white. This will keep the crust from getting soggy later. Cut a banana into slices. Make the slices ⁄4 to ⁄2 inch (0.6 to 1.3 cm) thick. Line the second pie crust with the slices. Set your oven to preheat at 350ºF. From this point, you need to work quickly so that your oven does not get too hot before you put the pie in. Pour the pie filling, which has been sitting in the refrigerator, into the pie crust (over the top of the bananas). Smooth it with the rounded side of a big spoon. Create a lattice top on the pie, using the strips prepared in Step 3. With a fork, press the ends down onto the crust. Use a little bit of water to help stick if they do not stick of their own accord. Brush the lattice top strips with egg white and sprinkle with sugar and cinnamon.  Wrap the crust in foil. Doing this helps to prevent the crust from burning on the edges before the center of the pie is thoroughly cooked. Place the pie into the center of the oven. Cook for 50 minutes. Remove the pie and let it cool for at least an hour before you eat it.
